comments.commentBody: Nobody, but NOBODY, can come close to Trump in the ability to push all failures onto other people!

The flurry of early voting by Hispanics, while a good thing, may be more a reflection of massive activity by Hillary's machine, than a trend that will continue over into the voting tomorrow.

But one thing is sure - those Hispanics who voted against him, stood up and did their part to protect our country from bigotry, idiocy, and just plain bad manners.

I hope many more Hispanics, and Americans of every color, persuasion, and national background, come to the polls tomorrow to torpedo Trump.

Send him down - all the way down.

shesheshe, Are you referring to " many more Hispanics, and Americans of every color, persuasion, and national background"? It seems like a noble statement, not pejorative. Maybe you misread it, or you are referring to something else?

Not to be the police of the comments section, just tired of so many misunderstandings and misrepresentations going unaddressed and unresolved. Most people are basically decent, but the process is not letting anyone complete their thoughts or think things through together in collaboration and debate. Cheers.

Isn't the U.S. a box? 'People'(vs animals) is also a box. Making distinctions should not in itself be considered pejorative, given that people do seem to come in many colors, shapes, backgrounds. The idea shouldn't be to force an artificial conceptual unity out of all the distinctions that can be noted among us, but to multiply those distinctions to the point where none have any power to dominate the others(even the domination of correct speech over diverse speech).
Don't you think Hilary's machine will continue to do all it can to get out the Latino vote tomorrow? Why wouldn't it?
And you are Mark Thomason, just as I'm Joschka (Jim Kay in real life.)
Sunset? I don't think so. More like mid-afternoon!

Some fable you wrote!

You think Hillary's story just reflects the aging from youthful idealism to establishment realism? I see her story as youthful idealism, first as a Goldwater Girl, then the Wellesley senior who challenged the slow pace of change (that one I would have gladly voted for). Then she got smitten by greed for money and power and didn't let idealism get in her way.

Then there's Bernie, of the same boomer generation, who also gained political prominence, who also aged and had grandchildren. But he remained true to his ideals. The difference between the two has nothing to do with their generation; it has to do with who they really are.

And Trump? So as not to get censored, I'll just say he's one of a kind; not to be marked by/with any generation.

Democrats have also bought into lower taxes and lack of investment in infrastructure. Obama has not proved to be a dove. Obama's eight years are virtually over and we still blame Bush for Obama's failure to get us out of the Mid East quickly? Hillary has only really double-downed appealing to the working class when she realized Trump was making inroads there. Neither she nor Bill came from super rich backgrounds but they do seem to have forgotten their roots.

Mind you I am a Democrat and voted for Obama in 2008 and 2012 and have already cast my vote for Hillary. She is the best alternative to a deranged demagogue. But she is not the best the Dems could have put forward. And I am not talking about Bernie. Joe Biden is a person who has not forgotten his roots while growing with the times. Don't forget he was out in front of Obama on same sex marriage. No one could accuse him of what she is being accused of. She is not clean, though hardly as dirty as Trump or some in the FBI would have us believe.

Yes, the Democrats are a far better alternative to Trump, Giuliani, Ryan et. al. Saying that Trump's tax plan is inconsistent with what brought prosperity in the past is accurate. But, "voting accordingly" for the alternative who does not really support high tax rates and understand the suffering of many in the working class including (gasp) less educated white makes is not entirely consoling.
Neither Ford or Kennedy were lawyers with political careers before they met their husbands.

Hi, Jeff -

As one boomer to another, I completely disagree with you. The last meaningful, positive thing our generation did was protest against the Vietnam War. Starting with the presidency of Bill Clinton, we turned our collective backs on our country's working class, diddled while climate change became worse, enjoyed our gadgets, and buried the Greatest Generation that came before us.

And the millennials you so scorn will have to clean up the mess we left.

It matters because I like Clinton and I hope she is elected now and again in 2020. But there is 2024 to think about!

I would be supporting Clinton no matter which of the 17 GOP contenders had won. I think that is some evidence that she is a pretty good choice.

Gen X'er here: I think most Millennials want opportunities to work towards those things, but the cards are stacked against them coming out of their educations in ways they were not against the Boomers or even us 15 years ago (student loans to cover the insanely high cost of today's tuition, depressed & globalized job market). Also, their parents gave them a ton of advantages (unlimited device time), but didn't teach them a lot of skills that you and I learned or denied them certain freedoms we enjoyed (playing outside alone with friends, not having every minute scheduled). That's why they're more socially awkward/neurotic than we are and why they may come across as aloof (and therefore lazy), but that's on their parents. But due to the intense competitive pressures they face at every level now (school, job, etc.) the one thing that many of them are not, is lazy.

The poll doesn't separate out gender, so we do't know whether there is a gender difference. However, in every major national poll the has been a dramatic difference between how white men and women are voting.

The poll shows that 50% of college-educated folk are for Trump and 41% for Clinton. It is whites with no degree who are at 67%.

Sounds like all that was missing were the white sheets and hoods and the burning crosses.  As for the leftover signs and empty popcorn tubs littering the floor, I'm guessing that the Klan at least has the decency to clean up after itself.
They probably pay immigrants (very little) to do that.

CY YOUNG

(sigh)

First, to compare the rate of turnover of coaches in American sports to the EPL (and European Football generally) is laughable at best.  Second, "Soccernomics" proved through statistical analysis that the greatest predictor of success is wage spending and that managerial spending results in very little success variation.  My argument isn't necessarily that coaches have no impact on a match, it's simply that a coach can only go so far to overcome a complete lack of professional squad talent (or a complete lack of relative investment in squad talent).  Swansea are not a good team.  The fans are blaming everyone but the team.  It's weird.  Really, really weird.  Give the guy a chance to spend some money.
love that about the times.

"Soccernomics" argued through empirical analysis that football managers have little impact on team success.  The greatest predictor of team success is player wages.  That's a fact proven by science.  Fergie would not have won 13 titles managing Swansea.  Soccer is different than other sports.  It's free flowing (that's why I love it).  Player ingenuity generally wins matches.  It's certainly not micromanaged mid-match (anyone who's actually played knows this to be true).  I'd argue that a vocal centreback or keeper have more mid-match managerial control than the vaunted gaffers.  I think you give too much credit to Big Sam and Tony Pulis, and are way too harsh on Bradley (and I think Swansea was hard on Guidolin).

51, not 15. And I didn't mention that the obdurate ones are all Republicans.

Though perhaps I insult Republicans to associate them with the current ones in office, who hardly deserve the name. Conservation is conservative, used to be.

And the truth matters. I understand top climate scientists James Hansen, Kerry Emanuel, and Richard Alley used to be Republican.

Lemmings of the world, toddlers, apes, and all others who have been compared to Trump and teapublicans, unite and be disgusted!

Well, as they say, there's always a first time.  And I hope and pray yours will come tomorrow because if Trump wins you might not have another presidential election outcome to predict.  A Trump presidency would bring us to the brink of social disintegration.  But, if he wins we can always hope he gets impeached and is forced to resign. Pence is no leader but I do not think he is completely crazy.

Is that a huge tumor or just your tongue in your cheek?

If your piece was a little more focused, it would be good satire.

Hm. It amazes me that even after more than 50 years, American media still puts Boomers in the predictable bracket. I suppose given the fact that the usual assumption that people are as two dimensional as media and its very brief attention spans is also rather predictable.

Just remember that the Boomers were the first to go outside the ancient system that doesn't work at all now and barely worked back then. The counterculture was quite real, and functional.

The main reason for overall regression on all subjects is that the media allows these primitive cave dwellers space on TV and the net. If you don't like ancient genocidal planet-destroying crocks, stop giving them so much credibility. If some nut on the street said half of what's come out of this election, they'd be locked up, not considered "representative" of anything.

Also stop presenting this unsightly mess as if it was some sort of Boomer idea. It wasn't, and isn't. "Entitlement" was fought for, like rights, meds prices and everything else, in the face of this grotesque tyranny of corruption and greed. What's happening is that those basic rights and entitlements are being stolen, every single day. If you want to be medieval serfs, wallowing in endless catastrophes, just keep ignoring the fact that this is happening now, not 50 years ago.

Keep blaming the past, and see what spectator criticism without action achieves. Zip. Nada. Nil. As for "sunsets", this garbage will be riding off in to it long before we do.

Obama's legacy: BLM, Trump and the AltRight.  Cultural Marxism pushed too far too fast.  If diversity promoters had shown a bit more restraint, white counter-movement would not have risen.  But now it has.  From now on: all politics is identity politics.  May the best tribe win.
"Restraint" being to not elect a brilliant constitutional scholar president because he is black?

By American standards, yes, 12th is awful.  And, not for nothing, last season was a bit of an outlier, to say the least.  I bet your Sunday afternoon pub team could have avoided relegation last season.
This show has gotten terrible. What happened?

Trump happened.  He is a tremendous evil that pollutes everything, and now America is doomed.  So at least this is a nice little distraction from the horrible things that will happen in our once-great nation next year.

Really?
Isn't there anywhere one can go to get away from this constant political, partisan bickering?
Was that the least bit necessary in the comments section regarding a fictional television series?
Give it a rest.

I've watched all six episodes and I've tried to take the show as seriously as Scott Tobias, but I just can't. He says this is all about questions of life's meaning and control and all I see is a young lady in a haunted house and a monster in the dark. And the set up was hardly original - who didn't know what was going to happen the moment she said "I'm going to check this out." A lot of dangling hints and teases and I sill think we'll finally get to Ed Harris is Arnold. There's a reason his character has no name - because the name would give him away. And a whole lot of teased nudity for no good reason. Having come this far, I guess I'll stick out the last four episodes and maybe I'll be surprised in a sort of Norman's mother is a corpse sort of way. But enlightened, made to see my existence in a new light. I'd be surprised.
